description: From Middle English arvell, from Old Norse erfiǫl (“a funeral feast”), from arfr (“inheritance”) + öl (“ale”). Cognate with Danish arveøl (“a wake, funeral feast”). More at erf, ale.

entries.meaning: (Scotland and Northern England, now rare) A funeral feast or wake at which bread and ale was served, traditional in Scotland, the North of England, and among the Norse.
examples: It was customary in the north to have an arval or funeral dinner after an interment.

entries.meaning: (rare, chiefly historical) The ale served at such a wake, the drinking of which was a ritually significant act in Norse culture.
examples: […]  Then quoth Hamtheow, etc.: 'We shall never come back to our mother [when we have slain the King of Goths]. Thou shalt drink the arval for us all together, for Swanhild and thy sons.'

entries.meaning: (Lancashire) The money given to hunters, at the death of a fox, in order to buy ale.
